page.title: 02LANDSCAPE OF HOLYWELL
page.content: The limestone plateau of Halkyn Mountain dominates our area,reaching a {height of 837ft}at Penyball.This is open country dotted with outcrops of Carboniferous limestone.Falling to about{500ft,}the line of the A55 Road to Holywell skirts the plateau.Several streams cut into the lower slopes of the Holywell shales and coal measures which fall more gently to the Dee fore shore.These valleys are deep and well wooded and the most significant is that leading from Holywell known as the{Greenfield Valley.}This is followed by the stream derived from {the Well}from which Holywell takes its name. Clays,sands and pebbles are found covering the area,left by the Pleistocene Glaciation.The Dee fore- shore is reclaimed marshland and the steep slope on the A548 at Greenfield marks the former cliff coastline.
